Award.AwardTitle: Hormone-Responsive Electrodes for Quantitative Discourse with Endocrine Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Number: 1403495
Principal Investigator: Christopher J. Easley
Title: Hormone-Responsive Electrodes for Quantitative Discourse with Endocrine Cells

General

Biological systems communicate using cascades of molecular signals, exploiting numerous feedback control loops similar to automobile cruise control. To aid our understanding of these systems, there remains a need for materials that respond to biological signaling molecules such as proteins and DNA. We have developed measurement techniques (proximity assays) that can respond to very low levels of proteins, translate this signal into controlled DNA binding, then communicate the signal to an electrode for recording protein quantity. These techniques can also release DNA strands in proportional amounts to input proteins. The main objective of this proposal is to show that our surface-based proximity assays can sense hormone levels secreted by endocrine cells, then respond proportionally by releasing agents that modify secretion. Upon completion, we will have developed a tunable "cruise control" system for hormone secretion, one that should allow cell culture systems in the laboratory to more closely mimic their natural biological environment.

Technical

Our recently developed proximity-based protein assays are based on cooperative assembly of dual proximity probes, and they are highly sensitive and generalizable to essentially any protein with two available antibodies (or aptamers). These assays decouple target binding from the reporting mechanism by exploiting DNA hybridization and/or strand displacement reactions. We propose that our proximity assay format is amenable to two-way communication, rather than the one-way information transfer in typical biosensing systems. The objective of this proposal is to show that surface-based proximity assays can sense hormone levels secreted by endocrine cells, then respond proportionally by releasing agents that modify secretion. Such hormone-responsive electrodes could generate new paradigms in cell culture and allow endocrine tissue to be monitored in more in vivo like, responsive environments. Completion of our objective through the following goals will deliver transformative impacts in biosensing, responsive materials, and synthetic biology: 1) Develop an entirely surface-bound electrochemical proximity assay, 2) Synthesize functional DNA-drug conjugates, and 3) Develop hormone-responsive electrodes for quantitative communication from surfaces, through DNA circuits, and to living endocrine cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major objective of the research funded by this NSF award was to improve our fundamental understanding of electrochemical measurements of biologically important molecules. Electrochemistry has proven to be one of the most suitable technologies for rapid, point-of-care analysis due its simple instrumentation, among other benefits. A prime example is continuous glucose monitors used commonly by diabetics. However, very few molecules can currently be detected with these systems, while there are many thousands of important biological molecules of interest. By designing and building electrochemical systems that can detect molecules secreted by endocrine cells, our laboratory seeks to close this gap in detectable analytes. With the funding from this award, we have uncovered several important features for designing more generalizable electrochemical biosensors, solidifying the intellectual merit of this project. We have shown that DNA-controlled, nanometer scale positioning of binding molecules at gold electrode surfaces can give us clear changes in electrochemical currents in response to molecules of interest. The latest iteration of our sensors includes a DNA nanostructure that can be adapted to detect small molecules (steroid molecules) or large protein molecules (antibodies) that are relevant in biological and medical fields, and other versions of our sensors can detect microRNA molecules directly in human serum. Along the way, we have also improved our intellectual understanding of signal dependences on DNA tether lengths, temperature, and pulse frequency using our chosen electrochemical technique, square-wave voltammetry (SWV).

With respect to the broader impacts of this work, our advancements have been disseminated in a number of publications, including peer-reviewed journal articles, patents and patent applications, talks and posters at conferences, a Master’s thesis, and several Ph.D. level dissertations. Seven graduate students (4 female, 3 male) and two undergraduate researchers (1 female, 1 male) were directly impacted by this funding, including two from underrepresented minorities. Community outreach efforts were also undertaken as part of this project, in conjunction with additional NSF funding and a partnership with Tuskegee University and other nearby institutions. Middle-school teachers in the area were trained on science modules that were integrated into their classroom curricula, and the modules were continuously informed by the understanding gained through our experimental science.

Overall, with the improved understanding of our analytical systems enabled by this funding, we have: 1) developed new electrochemical measurement methods and similar optical approaches for both small and large biomolecules, 2) constructed new instruments for both temperature-dependent electrochemistry and DNA melting analysis at electrodes, 3) invented a new potentiostat instrument that should be applicable to any DNA or RNA-based measurements at electrodes, 4) invented a new DNA nanostructure that can be adapted to detect a wide range of molecules, and 5) improved our basic understanding of how DNA-based positioning of signaling molecules occurs at electrode surfaces. This work, which was disseminated to the public through various routes, has provided an important step forward in the search for more generalized biomolecule detection platforms.
